Frederik DeVilder
  • Which Array Method To Use
    • Which array method is best for what situation?
      • To mutate original array
      • A new array
      • An array index
      • Know if array includes
      • To transform to value
      • An array element
      • A new string
      • To just loop array

Which Array Method To Use

Which array method is best for what situation?

To mutate original array

ðŸ‘‰ Add to original:

  • .push (end)

    Places a value at the end of an array.

  • .unshift (start)

    Puts a value at the start of the array.

ðŸ‘‰ Remove from original:

  • .pop (end)

    Removes a retrievable value from the end of the array.

  • .shift (start)

    Removes a retrievable value from the start of the array.

  • splice (any) â–º .splice([startIndex], [countFromIndex])

    Similar to slice, except that it MUTATES THE ORIGINAL ARRAY. It's second parameter counts the elements to delete.

ðŸ‘‰ Others:

  • .reverse

    Reverses the array.

  • .sort â–º .sort(([current], [next]) => a - b))

    Sorts the array based on conditions comparing the current and the next element.

  • .fill â–º .fill([value], [start], [end])

    Fills an empty of occupied array according to the condition arguments.

A new array

ðŸ‘‰ Computed from original:

  • .map (loop) â–º .map(([current], [index], [array]) => {-operation-})

    Iterates an existing array and creates a new array from the results.

ðŸ‘‰ Filtered using condition:

  • .filter â–º .filter(function([current], [index], [array]) => {-operation})

    Returns the elements of an array that pass the conditions of the filter method.

ðŸ‘‰ Portion of original:

  • .slice â–º .slice([startIndex],[endIndex])

    Removes a retrievable part of the array.

ðŸ‘‰ Adding original to other:

  • .concat â–º .concat([arrayToAdd])

    Adds all items from one array to another array.

ðŸ‘‰ Flattening the original:

  • .flat â–º Array.flat([depth])

    Flattens arrays with multiple levels into a 1-level array. The function argument defines the max depth it should look in.

  • .flatMap â–º .flatMap([current] => {-operation-})

    Returns items from a map that fulfil a condition and places these into a flat array.

An array index

ðŸ‘‰ Based on value:

  • indexOf

    Returns the index of the element within the array (0-based).

ðŸ‘‰ Based on test condition:

  • findIndex â–º .findIndex([current] => {-condition-})

    Finds the index of an item that fulfils the conditions.

Know if array includes

ðŸ‘‰ Based on values:

  • .includes â–º .includes([value])

    Results in a boolean based on wether a value exists within an array.

ðŸ‘‰ Based on test conditions:

  • .some â–º .some([current] => {-conditions-})

    Checks an array for any items that fulfil the conditions.

  • .every â–º .every([current] => {-conditions-})

    Checks if ALL array items fulfil the conditions.

To transform to value

ðŸ‘‰ Based on accumulator:

  • .reduce â–º .reduce(([accumulator], [current], [index], [array]) => {-operation-}, [startingValue])

    Reduces all items of an array to a single value.

An array element

ðŸ‘‰ Based on test conditions:

  • .find â–º .find([current] => {-condition-})

    Retrieves a value from an array based on a condition.

A new string

ðŸ‘‰ Based on separator string:

  • join â–º .join(['separator'])

    Joins all elements of an array into a string, mended by a separating character.

To just loop array

ðŸ‘‰ Based on callback:

  • .forEach (iterates existing array) â–º .forEach([callback] ([currentItem], [currentIndex], [entireArray]) => {-operation-})

    Iterates an existing array, computing an operation at every element.
